report_title: Operating Systems & Productivity Software Publishing in the US
executive_summary: The major companies writing operating systems (think Microsoft, Apple, Google) have become some of the world's largest, primarily due to their omnipresence in the devices people use almost hourly across much of the world. Over the past 20 years, industry revenue more than tripled, untouched by the Great Recession and boosted by the pandemic. Microsoft Word and Excel have enabled executives and schoolchildren to command words and numbers easily. The industry has been richly rewarded for these world-changing applications, with revenue climbing at a CAGR of 6.9% to $160.4 billion in 2023, with profit reaching 15.8% and revenue rising 2.1% in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Drives High Revenue at a High Cost to Talent
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry talent has fled for smaller companies across the tech sector, as significant developers strained against developers' limits in 2020 without proportionally expanding time off and health benefits. European regulators continue striking at the tech giants with privacy and antimonopoly legislation, causing significant internal bleeding. Cyberattacks and global conflicts are also poking holes in the digital global market rapidly. Open-source, free software, led by Linux, has finally become a viable option for technical home users. With the size and necessity of digital productivity tools, the operating system and productivity software developers will not lose revenue. Still, growth will slow, rising at a CAGR of 0.9% to $168.2 billion from 2023 to 2028.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Still, developers should be able to recover
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New operating system technology and productivity software may soon become uncoupled from single devices and be accessible through the cloud, working equally well from a desktop, laptop, phone and tablet. Productivity subscriptions will continue to bring in value year after year. The tools created in this industry build the world and will keep productivity software and operating systems on the desktops of computers for a long time.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE PANDEMIC STALLS AND MAY REVERSE GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: For the first time since 2010, operating system and productivity software coders may generate less income in 2023. A looming recession, increased scrutiny of technology companies, diminished public image and market saturation each play a role. The economy runs on computers regardless, and tech companies will continue to leverage that advantage.

Computers, phones and watches used to run entirely separately, with very few features linking them together. This will shortly no longer be the case. Windows, Linux and Android are battling MacOS and iOS to add new cross-device features: viewing phone notifications on a computer, signing into a laptop with a phone's fingerprint sensor and running phone apps on a desktop may soon be ubiquitous. Intense code mergers on the backend will also minimize developers translating code from one device class to another.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: UNSATISFIED EMPLOYEES ARE CONTINUING TO LEAVE TECH JOBS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry value added grew more than 20.0% in 2020, which came at a steep cost to employees: 60-to-80-hour workweeks, the looming threat of being let go and pandemic fears cracked many workers to the point of breaking. Tech companies were the hardest hit, with workers walking out, protesting and demanding increased compensation and more ethical treatment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE CAN DRAW EXPONENTIAL REVENUE FROM BUSINESS CLIENTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large Language Model (LLM) systems popularized in late 2022 have compounded potential in operating system environments; the major developers of for-profit operating systems have all deployed or feverishly begun research on AI language model integrations. AI algorithms can easily predict what users will type next and suggest words and phrases accordingly, improve the accuracy and relevance of search results, and dramatically personalize the user experience by creating never-before-seen customizations. While operating systems have recently switched to a value-added-subscription model, the paradigm shift created by LLM systems has the potential to drive massive revenue, particularly from business customers who train custom models to learn their own environments.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry develop and publish operating systems and productivity software for computers and servers. An operating system is the interface with which computer users interact; productivity software includes basic applications, such as word processors, spreadsheets and slideshow creation tools. Companies may also generate revenue from tech support and software resales. This industry does not include computer hardware manufacturing or mobile phone operating system publishing.

key_trends: The digital world has transcended from lumps of silicon by code created by operating system and productivity software developers.
Upkeep and improvement for operating systems and software command an enormous price premium across nearly all economic sectors.

A once unshakable technology sector is beginning to decay from the inside. Regulators are poking holes in the power available regarding the devices people use to manage their lives, while employees are resigning at record rates after experiencing overwork and dehumanizing treatment.

Large companies creating software are technologically-diversified megaliths, integrating operating systems and productivity with numerous income streams. These companies almost always elect to release operating systems for free, knowing that increased revenue on other products and data collection will more than make up the loss.

Regulators have begun restricting the largest operating system and productivity software developers, citing anticompetitive practices, disregard for the environment and personal privacy violations. The European Union and California have taken the lead on this movement, though the Biden administration's word on the subject will carry the most weight for Microsoft, Apple and Google.

Diverse computing in every corner of the home, office and factory is providing opportunities for established and existing players alike. Traditional operating systems are highly wasteful on these embedded devices, so the industry is refocusing on power efficiency and quiet operation more than sheer performance.

Most operating systems are free, and those that aren't might want to consider it. Operating system giants have demonstrated that the downstream benefits to alternate software revenue more than make up for high sticker price for an OS.

Freelancer and individual purchases spiked massively during the pandemic, clawing back license seats from folding businesses and offices. Business ownership of software used at home is becoming the norm, though.

The pandemic has made offices almost irrelevant to most software developers. Technology companies have always been lenient when offering employees remote work packages, and very few require in-person attendance to this day.

Silicon valley is as popular as ever to operating system and productivity software companies. Besides the prestige of an office in the birthplace of big tech, corporate clients are never too far away.

Competitive software companies offer a suite of interconnected business products appealing to a wide range of potential buyers. Having synergistic benefits between software is also a feature desired by time-strapped business clients.

Creating a software package for word processing or spreadsheet capabilities is a recipe for disaster. The 'Microsoft 365' subscription and availability of free alternatives push entrants into the less concentrated presentation, communication or supporting software sectors.

Complimentary services have become the core revenue generator for operating system developers. Apple+, Microsoft 365 and Google One each bring in revenue outstripping the cost of operating system development and are connected to each company's operating system with synergistic features.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Just as freelancing picked up during COVID-19, corporate office licenses in productivity and other software bled seats in the short term, as corporate offices with thousands of people reconfigured their licenses for home use.

Despite operating systems becoming far easier to install in the 21st century, consumers simply prefer the convenience of their operating systems being pre-installed by the assembler of their computer, such as Dell, Apple or HP.
When COVID collapsed much of the formal office economy, many solo creatives decided to turn their passions into careers using productivity software.

business_locations.location_description: Silicon Valley, a region of California named after the element used to make computer components, is famous around the world as a region densely packed with technology offices.
For operating system and productivity developers serving third-party markets directly, New York City and the Mid-Atlantic region is the productivity capital of the world.

Similar to the deserts that cover much of the region, technology companies in the Southwest region are building a diverse ecosystem of chip fabrication, hardware assembly and software development despite the harsh environment.

regulations_points.regulation_title: S O F T W A R E  P R O P E R T Y  L A W
regulations_points.regulation_description: The General Data Protection Regulation, enacted by the European Union in 2018, has expanded restrictions against user data abuse for all digital companies. As operating systems and productivity software are used internationally, all major players must comply with: 'The Right to be Forgotten,' which requires that digital companies verifiably purge all (non-safety related) data of a particular user on that user's request; and 'Privacy by Design', which mandates software at all levels consider the privacy and security of all users during software development, as opposed to only following release.

regulations_points.regulation_description: While the closure of most office spaces was devastating for operations in 2020, the development of remote employee support tools by operators and the wider world encouraged operators to cut costs by letting office leases lapse.

concentration_points.concentration_description: While writing an operating system is theoretically possible for one person, finding users willing to switch from Windows, Mac or Android is nearly impossible.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Market research and litigation keep the largest developers strong
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Developing a reliable, integrated operating system requires extensive research into client needs, existing offerings and future forecasting, all of which cost money. The US patent protection system forces operators spending to manage and register a portfolio of key code. Patent litigation costs have increased due to innovation, with the largest developers having their own litigation teams.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While developing operating system software requires thousands of labor-hours at a minimum, one individual with enough time can satisfy labor requirements by themselves. Success depends on employee skill and quantity, so labor-rich operators will benefit from more expedient returns.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Without an operating system, a computer is only a brick of silicon, metal and plastic. Operating system and productivity designers have remained partially insulated from swings in the technology industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INFLATION LIFTS VOLATILITY TO UNFORESEEN HEIGHTS
volatility_points.volatility_description: For numerous small business and individual purchasers of operating system and productivity software, rising inflation has raised the price of staple goods and minimized disposable income.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: Some companies, such as Alphabet via Google Docs, Sheets, etc., generate significant revenue through data collection, which is often sold to advertisers. Advertising has become more popular as a revenue source in recent years to make free-to-use software profitable. However, consumer opposition to these revenue generating methods is growing; those companies that can maintain user privacy or move to another funding model will likely experience improved public sentiment.

FAQs.question: How has the shift towards conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Large health provider networks are investing heavily in IT and software packages, with "more than 95% of providers expected to buy software in 2023", according to Bain&Company. Health software and operating systems are frequently many years out-of-date to remain compatible with older equipment; this investment will benefit the largest players the most, with many smaller developers getting few additional contracts. The pandemic stimulated a boost in the percentage of business conducted online in 2020, which fundamentally changed businesses to more online operations and lowered the cost of distributing physical media.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit? How is your company reacting to the new trend of remote work?
FAQs.answer: Major tech hubs include the Silicon Valley area of California, Austin, TX, Seattle, New York City and Boston. Although the aforementioned hubs are rapidly expanding, the pandemic has greatly increased the commonality of remote work, enabling new and smaller businesses to locate themselves anywhere.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: The industry is highly concentrated, so Microsoft and Apple, the industry's largest operators, have strongly contributed to rising wages.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: Individual computers are prime targets for hackers. Industry titan Microsoft frequently sends out security updates to protect against threats. High-profile data breaches in recent years have made this not only an operational necessity, but also one of importance for brand reputation. Demonstrating operational securing is becoming more important for securing business deals; consider working with a penetration testing team to ensure your software does not include any large security issues.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Changing interfaces are of significant importance to the popularity of operating systems and productivity software. Testing and trialing new interfaces, which are rolled out regularly by industry leaders to appear, "modern" and "accessible," is a crucial operating strategy used to gain popularity in this industry. Listening to aggregated public feedback from popular technology review sources may help your product avoid negative reception on release.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: As recruitment of highly-skilled workers has become more vital to success for the industry in recent years, it has become more important to work alongside industry associations and interest groups. Working with education providers at all levels has also been demonstrated to increase the size of talent pools across the industry.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation has played a small role in the industry to date, however public and federal scrutiny has soared in recent years. Larger companies should be aware of antitrust laws, as Microsoft and other companies have been scrutinized heavily on a federal level and are expected to face challenges from the Biden administration and European Union.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: Generally speaking, barriers to entry are higher in this industry than most other software industries because of the significant time, funding and manpower it takes to develop an operating system.

FAQs.question: What advantages do you offer to customers? What has your customer feedback been like since the pandemic began?
FAQs.answer: The dominance of Microsoft and Apple makes it difficult for startups to gain traction without securing funding. The cost of borrowing is anticipated to rise in the next several years as the federal reserve fights inflation.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'? How did the pandemic impact profitability last year?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins remained high in this industry in 2020, carried by Microsoft and Apple. However, smaller businesses with less reputable brand recognition struggled to maintain profitability last year.

FAQs.question: How does your company work to develop new products?
FAQs.answer: Software developers' financial success is often dependent on the release of new products or new versions of software. Subscription-based delivery models have increased the frequency of software updates and made them a more important component of client-retention since cloud computing reached the mainstream. Considering smaller, more frequent software updates in lieu of large changes may reduce your company's overall risk that an update goes badly and turns away customers.

FAQs.question: In what ways have you innovated your service offerings recently?
FAQs.answer: Software developers' financial success is often dependent on the release of new products or new versions of software. Subscription-based delivery models have increased the frequency of software updates and made them a more important component of client-retention since cloud computing reached the mainstream. Considering smaller, more frequent software updates in lieu of large changes may reduce your company's overall risk that an update goes badly and turns away customers.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a recognizable brand? How do you expand your installment base?
FAQs.answer: Sales of a particular operating system are strongly affected by the number of existing users. The more users of a particular operating system, the more likely developers are to publish compatible software, increasing demand. As businesses and consumers adopt new software systems, compatibility between users and companies has become a priority.

FAQs.question: How is the escalation in mobile internet connections influencing your software's design priorities, especially in terms of responsiveness and mobile-first strategies? In what ways are you leveraging the proliferation of mobile internet access to tap into emerging markets or demographics previously underrepresented online?
FAQs.answer: The surge in mobile internet connections globally underscores a pivotal shift towards mobile-first or mobile-only internet usage, significantly impacting operating systems and productivity software publishing. Companies that prioritize mobile responsiveness and intuitive design can capture a larger share of this expanding user base, enhancing their market position. Emerging markets are experiencing rapid growth in mobile internet penetration, presenting untapped opportunities for software publishers. By tailoring offerings to the needs and preferences of these new users, companies can build loyalty and establish strong brand presence early on, ahead of competitors slow to adapt to these demographic shifts.

FAQs.question: How is your product adapting to the increasing percentage of business activities conducted online, in terms of security features and integration capabilities?
FAQs.answer: As more business operations migrate online, the demand for secure, reliable, and integrated software solutions escalates. Operating systems and productivity software that offer enhanced security features and seamless integration with other online tools can gain a competitive edge, as businesses seek to safeguard their digital assets and streamline operations.

FAQs.question: With a higher volume of transactions moving online, what strategies are you implementing to ensure your software solutions enhance user productivity and efficiency in a digital-first business environment?
FAQs.answer: The shift towards digital-first business practices necessitates software that not only supports but elevates online productivity and efficiency. Publishers that focus on developing intuitive, feature-rich solutions can help users navigate and excel in an increasingly online business landscape, fostering customer satisfaction and long-term loyalty.

FAQs.question: How is your company positioning its products in response to trends in private investment in computers and software, particularly regarding scalability and return on investment (ROI)? Given the fluctuations in private investment levels, how are you ensuring your software remains attractive to both small enterprises and large corporations, in terms of cost-effectiveness and value proposition?
FAQs.answer: The trend in private investment towards computers and software highlights a growing recognition of technology as a key driver of competitiveness and efficiency. Publishers that emphasize scalability and clear ROI in their offerings can appeal to businesses looking to maximize their technology investments, securing a loyal customer base across varying economic cycles. Fluctuating investment levels necessitate a flexible approach to pricing and value proposition. By offering cost-effective solutions that deliver tangible benefits, software publishers can maintain appeal across a broad spectrum of businesses, from startups to multinational corporations, ensuring steady demand even in less favorable economic conditions.
